Questions.Question: According to the lesson, what migration pattern did Sam teach Riley to use for PetAdopt?
Options: Big Bang Rewrite - rewrite everything at once
Strangler Fig Pattern - gradually replace old code
Feature Toggle Pattern - hide new code behind flags
Blue-Green Deployment - run two complete systems
Questions.Explanation: Sam recommended the Strangler Fig Pattern, where new hexagonal code gradually replaces old code like a strangler fig tree enveloping its host - no risky big-bang rewrites.

Questions.Question: According to the lesson, a big-bang rewrite is the recommended approach because it's faster than incremental migration.
Questions.Explanation: The lesson explicitly warns against big-bang rewrites. They're risky, often fail, and delay value delivery. Incremental migration with the Strangler Fig pattern is safer and delivers value continuously.

Questions.Question: According to the lesson, what were the results of Riley's PetAdopt migration? Select ALL that apply.
Options: Deploy time dropped from 2 hours to 15 minutes
The migration took 4 weeks of incremental work
They had to stop all development during migration
Questions.Explanation: Riley's migration achieved 81% coverage, 15-minute deploys, in 4 weeks of incremental work. The key benefit was that development continued throughout - they didn't have to stop.

Questions.Question: According to the lesson, the first step in migration is to _______ the domain by moving business logic out of handlers into pure domain objects.
Questions.Explanation: The migration strategy starts with extracting the domain - identifying business rules in handlers and moving them into proper entities and value objects in a pure domain layer.
